page.title: 03Fryerning Church
page.content: The church stands in a commanding position overlooking most of the surrounding area. The exterior is mainly of pudding stone, with flint and quartz pebbles. The nave is the oldest part of the building, dating from the 11th century, and the walls, which are three feet (one metre) thick, contain five Norman windows. The brick tower dates from the early 16th century, when it was constructed by the Knights Hospitallers to replace an earlier wooden one. In 1869, the church was restored for about Â£1400 and the appearance of the interior mainly reflects that time. The most interesting parts of the church have separate pages devoted to them.
